title: Trump's New Shutdown World
summary: In 2013, Obama tried to maximize the difficulty. OMB is taking another tack.. This weekend the federal shutdown becomes the longest in history-and yet, and yet, the sky has not fallen. Meet the team that has allowed the Trump White House to hold out for so long, and in the process forever altered future shutdown fights.

title: Politics May Trip Up Amazon and Walmart in India
summary: The country isn't too big for foreign companies to walk away from or avoid.. Does India want foreign investment? Since his election in 2014, Prime Minister Narendra Modi has ardently wooed global business leaders. He once declared that FDI stands for "First Develop India." Last month Commerce Minister Suresh Prabhu touted plans to attract $100 billion in foreign investment over two years.

title: Protecting Tenants and Expanding Ferry Service on Mayor's Plate This Year
summary: De Blasio continues his 'tale of two cities' theme in his sixth State of the City address. In Mayor Bill de Blasio's sixth year in office, New York City residents should expect to see more safeguards against bad landlords, stronger workplace protection and improved transportation.

title: New York City Workplace Deaths Soared in 2017, Labor Report Says
summary: An increase in falls, slips and trips drove the jump in worker deaths. Workplace deaths in New York City rose 55% in 2017, although fatalities in the construction industry remained flat, according to a U.S. Department of Labor report released Thursday.

title: Amazon's IMDb Launches Free Streaming-Video Service
summary: IMDb Freedive features a catalog of movies and TV shows and requires no subscription. Amazon.com Inc. launched its first advertising-supported streaming-video channel, the e-commerce giant's latest effort to grab a larger share of the ad market.

title: Junk-Bond Sale Ends 40-Day Market Drought
summary: Deal follows record dry spell that began in November, suggesting an improving corporate-debt market. A long freeze in the junk bond market thawed Thursday as midstream energy company Targa Resources Partners LP became the first business to sell below-investment-grade bonds since November.

title: Copper Edges Lower After More Weak China Data
summary: Consumer prices rise at their slowest pace in six months. Copper prices dropped slightly Thursday following the latest round of weak Chinese economic data, with analysts still fearing a slowdown in growth and lower demand for industrial materials.

title: Fed's Powell Affirms Flexible Rate Outlook
summary: Powell says muted inflation will give central bank ability to be patient on interest rates. WASHINGTON-Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell reiterated Thursday the central bank would be patient in raising interest rates this year after global growth worries gripped financial markets in recent weeks.

title: Trump Cancels Davos Trip, Digs In on Border-Wall Funding
summary: President says he may declare national emergency if talks fail, and that he won't travel to World Economic Forum amid shutdown. WASHINGTON-President Trump on Thursday canceled a trip to the World Economic Forum summit in Davos, Switzerland, and reasserted his willingness to declare a national emergency to pay for the border wall as the partial government shutdown neared the longest in history.

title: New Target CFO Will Have to Sustain Retailer's Turnaround Pace
summary: Retailer stepped up capital expenditure, forecast at $3.5 billion last year, as part of its overhaul efforts. Target Corp. is launching its search for a new finance chief at a crucial time: After a strong holiday season, the Minneapolis-based retailer needs to keep the momentum going while experimenting with new ways to reach its customers to compete with e-commerce rivals.

title: Pompeo Courts Arab Support Against Iran While Touting U.S.'s Mideast Role
summary: Speaking in Cairo, secretary of state casts the Islamic Republic as the Trump administration's top concern in the region while blasting Obama's approach. CAIRO-U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo used a speech here to rally the Arab world against Iran, casting the Islamic Republic as the Trump administration's top concern in the region at a pivotal moment in U.S.-Mideast relations.

title: U.S. Stocks Regain Ground Despite Concerns About Global Growth
summary: Shares rebound after Powell's remarks reinforce the Fed's willingness to adjust pace of rate increases. The S&P 500 recouped an early loss to clinch its fifth straight session of gains after Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powellreiterated the central bank's willingness to adjust its pace of interest-rate increases if economic conditions weaken.

title: New Florida GOP Governor Moves Quickly
summary: Ron DeSantis has opportunity to shift state's judiciary sharply to right, weighs steps on sheriff in Parkland shooting. MIAMI-Florida's new Republican governor, Ron DeSantis, is making a mark quickly in his first few days in office-moving the state Supreme Court to the right, unveiling a wide-ranging environmental plan and hinting he may take action against the sheriff who oversaw the response to the Parkland school shooting.

title: BlackRock Cutting Roughly 500 Jobs
summary: Money manager will shed about 3% of its staff in latest industry cost-reduction effort. BlackRock Inc. is cutting about 500 jobs as the world's largest money manager looks to simplify parts of its business and focus more on areas such as technology, retirement and alternative investments.

title: Mortgage Rates Hit Lowest Point in Nine Months
summary: Declines could propel more activity in the U.S. housing market. Mortgage rates fell again in the latest week, hitting their lowest point in the past nine months for both 15- and 30-year products, a move that could propel more activity in the U.S. housing market.

title: Cohen Will Testify Before House Oversight Committee
summary: Rep. Elijah Cummings said Cohen's Feb. 7 testimony would be voluntary. WASHINGTON-Michael Cohen, President Trump's former personal lawyer, will testify publicly before the House Oversight Committee next month, the panel's Democratic chairman said on Thursday.

title: Warrant Issued for Soccer Superstar Ronaldo's DNA in Rape Case
summary: After discovering DNA on dress of alleged victim, Las Vegas police want to know if it matches Ronaldo's. Authorities in Las Vegas have issued a warrant to obtain the DNA of soccer superstar Cristiano Ronaldo to see if it matches that found on a dress of a woman who has accused him of rape, according to a law-enforcement official with knowledge of the case.

title: Oil Extends Gains in Longest Winning Streak Since 2010
summary: Oil prices edge up as oversupply concerns recede amid weaker demand. • Oil prices settled higher on Thursday, notching their longest winning streak in nine years as fears of oversupply amid weaker demand abated.

title: U.K. Receives Record Number of Suspicious-Activity Reports
summary: Figures come amid debate about U.K. effectiveness against money laundering. U.K. crime fighters said they received a record number of reports between April 2017 and March 2018 concerning transactions with red flags for money laundering, terrorism financing or other financial crime.

title: A Bohemian Neighborhood in Peru Gets a Luxury Lift
summary: Lima's Barranco district gets renewed interest from wealthy homeowners drawn to its republican-era buildings, beach-town feel and easy access to restaurants and bars. Diego Rosselló long harbored a dream of buying a historic building in Lima and completing an authentic restoration. That pretty much meant he would be living in the Barranco neighborhood.

title: Fed Sent Lower Remittances to U.S. Treasury in 2018
summary: The Fed's expenses are rising as it raises short-term interest rates. WASHINGTON-Federal Reserve payments to the U.S. Treasury declined in 2018 as the central bank's expenses rose along with short-term interest rates.

title: U.S. Government Bonds Hold Steady
summary: Sale of 30-year Treasurys gets lackluster reception from investors and strengthening U.S. stocks reduce demand for safer assets. U.S. government bonds were little changed Thursday, retracing early gains following a soft auction of 30-year bonds.

title: How the Fed Showed It Had the Market's Back
summary: The size of the Federal Reserve's bond buying is less important than the signal the central bank sends. Does the Federal Reserve buying fewer Treasurys make the yield of the bonds go up or down? In the topsy-turvy world of Wall Street, the answer has reversed in just a few months.

title: 'The Road Ahead: Reimagining Mobility' Review: Future Imperfect
summary: An exhibition at the Cooper Hewitt looks at the coming transportation revolution, but the vision it presents can feel like a cold kind of utopianism..

title: 'True Detective' Review: Grim, Gripping Entertainment
summary: The third season of HBO's anthology series follows a pair of detectives haunted by the disappearance of two children.. It doesn't take long once the third season of "True Detective" begins (Sunday, 9 p.m., HBO) to feel the special weight of local atmosphere much the way season 1, memorably set in Louisiana, did. For series creator Nic Pizzolato's far more complex, darker and exquisitely layered new detective story, the location is Arkansas. Here a two-man detective team confronts a shocking crime-a theme, in season 1, whose energies were so intently focused on the relationship between Woody Harrelson's Detective Marty Hart and Matthew McConaughey's Detective Rust Cohle that the matter of the murder, and identity of the perpetrator, became ever less urgent.

title: 'The Dictator's Playbook' Review: Tyranny 101
summary: This PBS series looks at a half dozen 20th-century despots.. 'The Dictator's Playbook" (Wednesdays, 10 p.m., PBS) looks at six of the 20th century's most infamous despots with an eye to the characteristics common to them-the premise of the series being that dictators learn from one another. It's an absorbing, richly documented work. If the series has a flaw, it's the frequency of the academic commentaries-messages that expend a good deal of time in emphatic explanations of the obvious.

title: Tragedy of the Starbucks Commons
summary: Employees have just about had it maintaining public rest rooms.. Remember last spring when Starbucks chairman Howard Schultz announced shortly before departing the company that the coffee chain would allow everyone to use its rest rooms? His former colleagues have been left with quite a mess.

title: Temple University Settles Suit Over Fudged Data on M.B.A. Ranking
summary: University agrees to pay nearly $5.5 million to current and former business-school students. Temple University will pay nearly $5.5 million to settle a class-action lawsuit by current and former business-school students after the university acknowledged that its online M.B.A. program's top spot in a nationwide ranking was based on false data.

title: New York City Alleges Illegal Airbnb Hotel Ring in Manhattan
summary: Property owner is accused of letting hosts operate illegal short-term rentals in Manhattan. The Friday before New Year's Day, three tourists stood by a doorway on a Midtown Manhattan street, roller suitcases in hand. The visitors said they were waiting for directions to the apartment they booked on Airbnb Inc. Soon, a young woman led them to the lobby of a nearby building, the Cameo at 311 West 50th St.

title: We're Using, Not Abusing, Whistleblower Act
summary: The False Claims Act is widely regarded as an efficient and effective tool for rooting out health-care fraud.. The Journal editorial board's well-established disdain for trial lawyers gets in the way of understanding the issues at the heart of the False Claims Act whistleblower lawsuits we have filed against a group of large pharmaceutical companies ("Policing 'False' Claims," Dec. 27). You question the entrepreneur-based approach taken by the whistleblowers but fail to address the meat of our complaint-billing fraud, waste and abuse that can occur with Big Pharma's "white coat marketing" practice of placing corporate-funded nurse educators and billing staff inside private medical offices. It is naive to think of this as some form of corporate altruism. The government is duty-bound to scrutinize medical staff on a pharmaceutical company's payroll when these workers are masquerading as independent and objective providers of medical information. The Office of Inspector General, U.S. Department of Health and Human Services is clearly on record warning drug companies that this practice can violate anti-kickback statutes.

title: Third-Party Payers Muddy Drug Incentives
summary: When managing cost is in the hands of a third party such as Medicare or another insurer, profound waste is inevitable.. I was disheartened to read "Medicare Overpaid Insurers Billions" for prescription drugs (page one, Jan. 5). This is another example of the waste and dysfunction that results from third parties being involved in the dissemination of health care.

title: Owner of National Enquirer Refinances Debt
summary: American Media LLC said it refinanced its existing debt by raising $460 million in fresh loans. American Media LLC, the parent company of the National Enquirer and other magazines, said it refinanced its existing debt by raising $460 million in fresh loans.

title: Forget Soda; Tax Sugar in All Food Products
summary: Companies could be made to pay a "user fee" for all the sugar used in their products.. Your editorial "A Soda Tax and Consequences" (Jan. 5) highlights the problems of a good idea gone down the wrong road.

title: There May Be Surly Trains, but Good Manners Rule on the Q
summary: Whenever I enter a crowded train I hardly stand for one moment.. Regarding Alexandra Hudson's "I'm Taking the Surly Train" (op-ed, Dec. 26): I'm an 84-year-old woman who regularly rides between Brooklyn and Manhattan. Whenever I enter a crowded train I hardly stand for one moment: Someone-a man or woman, young or middle-aged-always stands and allows me to sit. Manners are still alive on the Q train!

title: Venezuelan Leader Starts Second Term With Grim Outlook
summary: Maduro's autocratic government helms a dysfunctional economy that is driving millions to flee. CARACAS-Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro was sworn in to a second, six-year term on Thursday in defiance of international calls to resign, paving the way for further isolation of a nation steeped in economic despair and autocracy.

title: Fiat Warns of $800 Million in Costs Related to Emissions Settlement
summary: Federal regulators allege auto maker used illegal software to dupe emissions tests in more than 100,000 diesel-engine pickup trucks and SUVs. Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV has agreed to pay nearly $800 million in fines and mitigation costs, and recall thousands of vehicles, to settle charges that it used illegal software to dupe emissions tests in more than 100,000 diesel-engine pickup trucks and SUVs.

title: Terror Group Seizes Last Syrian Opposition Stronghold
summary: Move threatens a fragile ceasefire between Russia and Turkey to forestall a Syrian government offensive. BEIRUT-A powerful extremist group seized control of most of Syria's last opposition stronghold on Thursday, threatening a fragile cease fire intended to avert a Syrian military offensive and likely humanitarian catastrophe.

title: Catholic Church Questions Surprise Congo Vote Results
summary: Vote is seen as a test of whether the mineral-rich but impoverished country can carry out a peaceful transfer of power. The Democratic Republic of Congo's powerful Catholic Church denounced official presidential election results on Thursday, stepping into a dispute that threatens the possibility of the country's first democratic transfer of power since independence.

title: Senator Collins Presses HHS to Reform Drug Rebate System
summary: Price increases resulting from rebates help to 'distort the pharmaceutical market,' Maine's Susan Collins says. The impact that rebates can have on prescription drug prices is drawing more scrutiny of the practice.

title: M.B.A.s, Do As I Say, Not as I Do
summary: Temple University's M.B.A. Program, which fudged data used in rankings but won't admit wrongdoing, is proud to offer you this ethics scholarship.. For years, Temple University boasted the top online Masters in Business Administration program in the country as ranked by U.S. News & World Report. Part of that ranking was the test scores of admitted students, which Temple now says it exaggerated.

title: 'The Upside' Review: Uplift on Demand
summary: Bryan Cranston and Kevin Hart star in the American adaptation of a film about the mismatched yet feel-good relationship between a quadriplegic and his caregiver.. As befits a dramatic comedy with an upper of a title, "The Upside" flies high in its inspirational climax, a parasailing sequence accompanied by Aretha Franklin, and not just Aretha Franklin but Aretha in her soaring rendition of the Puccini aria "Nessun Dorma." The film as a whole never takes flight, though not for lack of trying.

title: 'Techlash': Whipping Up Criticism of the Top Tech Companies
summary: The increasingly sharp rebukes of Facebook, Google and others now have a term of their own. A little over a year ago, when the Economist made predictions for "The World in 2018," one global theme that the magazine singled out was "the coming 'techlash.' " It described a reaction against Silicon Valley's tech giants such as Facebook , Google and Amazon, with growing calls for regulation and crackdowns on monopolistic policies.

title: Trump Administration Nears Release of New Overtime Proposal
summary: Labor Department is expected to broaden reach of overtime but by less than Obama administration attempted. WASHINGTON-The Labor Department sent its proposed overtime rule to the White House for review, which could allow the regulation determining how many Americans are entitled to extra pay when working more than 40 hours to be finished by late this year.

title: Lampert's Revised Bid for Sears Tops $5 Billion
summary: Edward Lampert's new bid would release the former CEO and his hedge fund from liabilities in exchange for $35 million payment to unsecured creditors. Edward Lampert, the billionaire who led Sears Holdings Corp. into bankruptcy, has increased his offer to more than $5 billion, in a last-ditch effort to keep the ailing retailer alive.

title: Treasury to Sell $88 Billion in Debt
summary: U.S. Treasury Department's auctions next week comprise 13- and 26-week bills and 10-year TIPS. The U.S. Treasury Department will auction $88 billion in securities next week. Details (all with minimum denominations of $100):

title: FBI Agents Group Says Shutdown Affects Law Enforcement
summary: Funding constraints, support personnel furloughs harm bureau's operations, association says. WASHINGTON-The head of an association representing thousands of Federal Bureau of Investigation agents said Thursday that the federal government's partial shutdown has begun to affect law enforcement operations, and he urged political leaders to end a stalemate that has stretched into its third week.

title: World Bank Lays Out Ground Rules for Selecting Next President
summary: Other countries may challenge U.S. on choosing successor to Jim Yong Kim. WASHINGTON-The World Bank said it would accept nominations from around the world for its next president starting next month, with a goal of having the new chief in office for the bank's spring meetings in early April.

title: 'Surviving R. Kelly' Sparks Debate and a Ratings Hit
summary: Lifetime's docuseries reaches more than 18 million viewers, though R. Kelly's attorney calls it 'a hit piece strictly for ratings'. The documentary series "Surviving R. Kelly" has become a ratings hit for Lifetime and reignited scrutiny and debate over the sexual-abuse allegations that have long swirled around the R&B singer.

title: The Sommelier Side Hustle: Winemaking
summary: Not content to merely recommend bottles, many sommeliers are getting into the business of making wine. Having sampled the results, our wine columnist offers some recommendations of her own. IN THE documentary "Somm 3," the latest in a series of sommelier-focused films, the somms aren't just tasting and recommending wines-they're making them, too.

title: Don't Take Stock in Oil's Rebound
summary: The return of risk appetite has lifted crude oil and stocks in tandem, but the fundamental reasons to push oil even higher look iffy. Oil's post-Christmas rally may be peaking.

title: 2019 Volvo V60: Why It's Time to Trade Your Crossover for a Wagon
summary: Crossovers and SUVs now dominate the family-vehicle market. But Volvo's V60 T6, a supercharged, turbocharged station wagon with great fuel efficiency and plenty of room, might be the brand's best car. Dan Neil tells us why. I'M SUCH A VOLVO-wagon stereotype: white-collar professional, married city-dweller with kids and...oh my lord, a degree in literature? They might as well hand out Volvo wagons with membership to the Modern Language Association.

title: American Airlines' Profit Warning Sends Carrier Shares Lower
summary: U.S. carriers aren't boosting revenue as much as expected. American Airlines Group Inc. trimmed its profit guidance for 2018, raising concerns that U.S. carriers are falling short of revenue expectations and sending shares down across the sector.

title: Why Only Some Retailers Got Their Holiday Wishes
summary: Macy's plunged on weak holiday sales, highlighting the divide between retailers that invested in stores and online sales. Investor expectations for U.S. retailers were high heading into the holidays. Low unemployment, rising wages and strong consumer confidence all boded well for spending; and several chains, like Sears and Toys "R" Us, had gone out of business. That meant market share for others to pick up. Even in a strong economy, though, not every retailer is going to win.

title: Sick of Hollywood Action Movies? Warhol's Epic Is an 8-Hour Shot of the Empire State Building
summary: With little happening on the silent screen, the focus is on the audience. 'You hear your own breathing...all of those bodily sounds, yours and others.'. Thomas Kiedrowski plans to bring a pillow to Saturday's screening of Andy Warhol's silent movie "Empire" in New York City.

title: One Way Shutdown is Hindering Business: Inaccessible IRS Numbers
summary: The agency has stopped issuing some tax ID numbers, a routine process that was taken for granted until it stopped. The partial government shutdown has left some companies unable to get a taxpayer identification number from the IRS, holding up routine business deals until the agency's workers return.

title: For U.K. Politics, Brexit Is Turning Into Groundhog Day
summary: U.K. government is expected to lose key vote next week-with no consensus on what to do next. LONDON- Britain's ongoing Brexit crisis is turning into Groundhog Day.

title: Minnesota Town's Shrimp-Farming Dreams Are Put on Ice
summary: With incentives, South Dakota and Minnesota compete for tiny trū Shrimp and its promise of indoor shrimp farms. A Minnesota town's dream of becoming the shrimp capital of the Midwest is proving more challenging than expected-and not just because of the weather.

title: Can Trump Build a Wall Under a National Emergency?
summary: A move by Trump to build a border wall might survive court challenges, but Congress could take steps to defund it. President Trump has reasserted his determination to declare a national emergency to fund a wall along the southern border.

title: The Bin Laden Attack That Two Presidents Failed to Answer
summary: Al Qaeda killed 17 U.S. sailors in its October 2000 bombing of the USS Cole, but neither the outgoing Clinton administration nor the incoming Bush administration retaliated. On New Year's Day, a Yemeni jihadist named Jamal al-Badawi was driving by himself east of the Yemeni capital of San'a, unaware that it was the last day of his life. He was killed by an American precision strike, according to U.S. defense officials. If Badawi felt surprise in his final moments, it may have been because he assumed that he had evaded justice-and because so few people now seem to remember the audacious and unanswered attack that he had once helped to plan.

title: A Generational Divide in the Uncanny Valley
summary: Adults find highly realistic imitations of human beings to be creepy, but young children don't see the problem. Over the holidays, my family confronted a profound generational divide. My grandchildren became obsessed with director Robert Zemeckis's 2009 animated film "A Christmas Carol," playing it over and over. But the grown-ups objected that the very realistic, almost-but-not-quite-human figures just seemed creepy.

title: Barranco Is Back
summary: Lima's affluent neighborhood is drawing luxury homebuyers with its authentic, arty vibe and active nightlife. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: America's Electric Grid Has a Vulnerable Back Door-and Russia Walked Through It
summary: A Wall Street Journal reconstruction of the worst known hack into the nation's power system reveals attacks on hundreds of small contractors. One morning in March 2017, Mike Vitello's work phone lighted up. Customers wanted to know about an odd email they had just received. What was the agreement he wanted signed? Where was the attachment?

title: Federal Employee Unemployment Claims Jump in Wake of Shutdown
summary: Broader jobless claims, a proxy for layoffs across the U.S., fell by 17,000 last week. WASHINGTON-The number of Americans filing new applications for unemployment benefits fell last week, but claims filed by federal employees jumped at the start of a partial government shutdown.

title: Ford Needs a Deal More Than Cuts
summary: Selling its European operations to Volkswagen in a GM-style exit would be better than restructuring them. Europe is a big market for auto makers, but it's hard to build the scale necessary to make decent profits. The restructuring plan that Ford announced on Thursday may help a bit. A merger-the exit route taken by GM-would be better.

title: Golf-Home Owners Find Themselves in a Hole
summary: Lawsuits pile up and fairways fall into disrepair as younger Americans shun golf, leaving behind homeowners who paid a premium for life on the links. When Mitch Steller first moved into his house on a lush 117-acre golf course in Southern California, "this was like the Garden of Eden, having a golf course in my backyard," he said.

title: An Online Tool to Catch Workplace Sexual Predators
summary: The nonprofit Callisto is bringing its digital reporting platform to the office. The goal: to identify repeat #MeToo offenders and protect their accusers. Women have long used word of mouth to warn each other about sexual predators, recognizing that offenders often target more than one individual. Lately, these so-called whisper networks have moved online and out of the shadows. Organizations such as the Silent Choir Project, JDoe and Callisto offer websites and mobile apps for survivors to report sexual misconduct and connect with victims of the same perpetrator, allowing them to explore legal options and come forward together.

title: Most Economists Expect Fed Will Hold Rates Steady at Least Until June
summary: In the latest WSJ survey, economists were split over whether Federal Reserve would raise benchmark federal-funds rates once or twice in 2019. Most private economists surveyed expect the Federal Reserve will hold interest rates steady at least until June, after Chairman Jerome Powell signaled the central bank may take a break from rate increases.

title: In a House With 16 Bathrooms, There Are Lots of Choices
summary: The proportion of homes with 10 or more bathrooms has nearly doubled in the past decade, as wealthy owners of luxury megamansions see an abundance of toilets as a covetable amenity. If he were so inclined, Alessandro Giacometti could stay two weeks at his Southampton, N.Y., home and use a different bathroom every day. The 12,000-square-foot house sits on 17 acres along Peconic Bay and has 10 bedrooms.

title: Humans: The Domesticated Primates
summary: As we became more peaceable, our bodies evolved along the lines of other tamed animals. A few years ago, I stayed in Kenya with the conservationists Karl and Kathy Ammann, who kept a rescued chimpanzee named Mzee in their home. Even as a young adult, Mzee was generally well-behaved and trustworthy. Yet he could be impulsive. At one point, over breakfast, Mzee and I reached for the jug of orange juice at the same time. He grabbed my hand as I held the jug, and he squeezed. Ouch. "You first!" I squeaked. I was still rubbing my fingers back to life once he had finished his drink.

title: Comscore's Local Momentum Signals Fresh Rivalry in Measurement Market
summary: Nexstar Media deal expands Comscore's customer roster of TV stations. Comscore Inc.'s new deal with TV station owner Nexstar Media Group Inc. is the latest sign the ad industry is warming to alternative TV currencies.

title: Focused on Sustainability, Graanmarkt 13 is a Go-To for Tastemakers
summary: The concept store and restaurant in Antwerp, Belgium, focuses on retail as personal expression. TWICE A YEAR, Graanmarkt 13, a concept store and restaurant in Antwerp, Belgium, reaches out to clients, but not to promote a new collection or a final-markdown sale. Instead, it asks customers to bring in old clothes, which the whole store then turns over to sell. Participants get a voucher to put toward new items.

title: Economists See U.S. Recession Risk Rising
summary: Survey finds more than half of economists see downturn by 2020, a presidential election year. Economists surveyed by The Wall Street Journal see a growing risk of recession in the U.S.

title: The High Cost of Financial Panics
summary: Roman emperors and American presidents alike have struggled to deal with sudden economic crashes. On January 12, 1819 Thomas Jefferson wrote to his friend Nathaniel Macon, "I have...entire confidence in the late and present Presidents...I slumber without fear." He did concede, though, that market fluctuations can trip up even the best governments. Jefferson was prescient: A few days later, the country plunged into a full-blown financial panic. The trigger was a collapse in the overseas cotton market, but the crisis had been building for months. The factors that led to the crash included the actions of the Second Bank of the United States, which had helped to fuel a real estate boom in the West only to reverse course suddenly and call in its loans.

title: The NFL Team With Road-Field Advantage
summary: The Los Angeles Chargers are undefeated-outside of Los Angeles. And that's why they can make a Super Bowl run.. Baltimore

title: Barnes & Noble Could Cut Earnings Outlook by Up to 10%
summary: The book retailer said comparable sales during the holiday season grew 4%. Barnes & Noble Inc. on Thursday cautioned investors that it could reduce its earnings guidance by up to 10%, citing higher spending on advertising and promotions.

title: Ford to Slash Jobs, Shut Plants in Major European Revamp
summary: Restructuring forms part of the U.S. auto giant's plan to turn around its global business. BERLIN- Ford Motor Co. is launching an overhaul of its money-losing European business that is expected to include thousands of job cuts, plant closures and the cancellation of low-profit models amid a series of bad news for global car makers.

title: How the U.S. Can Protect Corporate America's Tech Secrets From China
summary: There are specific measures that U.S. negotiators can pursue to slam the brakes on China's IP theft. After winding up three days of trade talks with China, U.S. negotiators said they pushed Beijing to implement structural reforms that would stop Chinese firms from prying technology away from their American rivals.

summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Thursday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

summary: For almost 90 years, the iconic art-deco tower has been an indelible part of Manhattan's landscape and made many cameo appearances on film. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: The Cleveland Browns Are Figuring Out Football
summary: A historic NFL punch line has a likable new coach, a star QB and (fingers crossed) an upbeat future. I don't need to tell you that this world of ours has gone mad. Just check the headlines: Up is down, down is up, truth is an illusion, the internet is a disaster, robots are coming for our jobs, people are singing in bizarre masks on television and the Cleveland Browns are...a football team with a promising future?

title: You & Mr Jones Takes Majority Stake in Internal Marketing Firm
summary: The 'brand-tech' company founded by David Jones is a majority stakeholder in six companies, the latest: Inside Ideas Group. You & Mr Jones Inc., the "brand tech" firm founded by former Havas SA Chief Executive David Jones, has acquired a majority stake in Inside Ideas Group Ltd., a London-based company that helps brands build their own internal marketing capabilities.

title: Kim and Xi Project Unity in Face of Stalled Nuclear Talks With U.S.
summary: At Beijing summit, leaders Kim and Xi press U.S. to compromise ahead of possible Trump-Kim meeting. The leaders of China and North Korea used a summit this week to project a show of unity in the face of stalled negotiations over Pyongyang's nuclear program and to press the U.S. to compromise.

title: CFOs Should Provide More Insight Into Natural Disaster Risks, Analysis Says
summary: Study from FM Global recommends finance chiefs spell out risks posed by climate change and adverse weather conditions. Finance chiefs world-wide could do a better job communicating the risks from natural disasters, according to an analysis of nearly 100 filings by FM Global, a mutual insurance company.

title: Missing Government Data Make Job Tougher for Policy Makers, Traders
summary: Agencies aren't releasing reports at a critical time for the Fed and others to read the economy.

title: GOP Solidarity Over Shutdown Faces Test Amid Voter Pressure
summary: Constituents put heat on Congress members, who fear 'holding those people hostage'. WASHINGTON-President Trump's call for solidarity among GOP senators on border-wall funding at a luncheon Wednesday came as Republican lawmakers face pressure from some constituents that is likely to intensify as the partial government shutdown drags on.

title: Nike's Dutch Tax Deals Under Scrutiny in Europe
summary: Several U.S. companies have been ordered to pay millions of euros to countries where they struck sweetheart tax deals. BRUSSELS-The European Commission on Thursday opened an investigation into Nike Inc.'s tax deals with the Netherlands, a move that could potentially force the U.S. company to pay back millions of euros.

title: The Beautiful Regularness of Lucas Hedges
summary: At 22, Hedges is already one of Hollywood's most accomplished young actors, but his meteoric rise has been anything but ordinary.

title: Apple's Pressing Challenge: Build Its Services Business
summary: Slowing iPhone sales heighten pressure to ignite a division with challenges of its own. Apple Inc. has held out its fast-growing services unit as a bright spot in an outlook dimmed by soft demand for the iPhone. But the services business faces challenges of its own.

title: Apple's Next Move: Be More Like Microsoft
summary: Owning an Apple device used to be the only way to access the company's services and software. Now that Apple is on the defensive, the walled garden may be holding it back from reaching vital audiences. Apple is making a small but radical shift in its corporate strategy. The company is blasting holes in the boundaries of its staunchly defended walled garden.

title: Target Sales Surged at Year-End, Capping Strong Holiday Season
summary: Retailer on track for strongest year of growth since 2005; Costco sales rose 7% at year end. Holiday sales rose at Target Corp. and Costco Wholesale Corp., an early sign that many retailers benefited from what was expected to be one of the strongest holiday shopping seasons in years.

title: U.S. Stops Some Exports From Huawei's Silicon Valley Unit
summary: R&D unit Futurewei is no longer able to send home some technologies developed in U.S.. Huawei Technologies Co. is contending with a new obstacle: getting technology it developed at a U.S. subsidiary back to China.

title: Chinese Overcapacity Returns to Haunt Global Industry
summary: Beijing's 'supply-side reforms' helped reduce global overcapacity-for a while. Chinese overcapacity is back. That's bad news for manufacturers world-wide-and for China's mounting debt problem.

title: Google Nears Win in Europe Over 'Right to Be Forgotten'
summary: Recommendation largely backs Google, which appealed a French order to apply the EU right to searches globally. Google and other search engines shouldn't be forced to apply the European Union's "right to be forgotten" beyond the bloc's borders, an adviser to the EU's top court said Thursday, citing a potential threat to free expression.

title: U.S.-China Trade Fight Shakes Global Economy, but Isn't All Bad for Bystanders
summary: Nations relying on steady world commerce prefer stability over short-term gains. Countries watching the U.S.-China trade talks from the sidelines are anxious for the two sides to reach a deal and avert the damage a protracted fight poses to the global economy-even if many see the potential to benefit from the dispute.

title: Samsung to Show Off Its New Foldable Phone in February
summary: Tech giant to also unveil its 10th anniversary flagship phones at events in San Francisco and London. SEOUL- Samsung Electronics Co. plans to unveil its 10th anniversary flagship phone lineup and show a fully functional foldable-screen handset at Feb. 20 events in San Francisco and London, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Stockpicker Jeffrey Vinik Plots His Third Comeback
summary: He will relaunch his hedge fund with former executives of Vinik Asset Management. Prominent stock picker Jeffrey Vinik is planning to relaunch his hedge-fund firm out of Tampa, Fla., in what would mark his third return to investing clients' money.

title: Next Stop, Elvis
summary: Elvis Presley fans and impersonators gather in Sydney's Central Station for a trip to the annual Elvis Festival in Parkes. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Trump Walks Out as Shutdown Talks Falter
summary: Emergency declaration by president to get money for the wall-shifted from the Pentagon-gains traction as an option. As negotiations to end a partial government shutdown broke down Wednesday, White House officials said an increasingly likely option is for President Trump to declare a national emergency over border security and try to use Pentagon funds to pay for construction of a wall or other barrier on the U.S.-Mexico border.

title: State-Backed Hackers Sought, Stole Singapore Leader's Medical Data
summary: Unprecedented breach led to theft of personal details of a quarter of the city-state's population, inquiry finds. SINGAPORE-State-sponsored hackers were likely behind a cyberattack that netted the personal details of 1.5 million people in Singapore, including the medical records of their primary target Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, an inquiry found.

title: China's Sluggish Prices Raise Deflation Fears
summary: Price indexes slowed in December, with the PPI increase hitting a two-year low. BEIJING-Consumer and producer prices decelerated sharply in China last month, compounding the challenge for Beijing in boosting sluggish demand in a deepening economic downturn.

title: Bad News for Avocado Growers = Good News for Millennials?
summary: Resume Subscription. Avocados may be the favored fruit for millennials. They're not proving a winner for investors, however.

title: Facial Recognition Priorities: Ethics Boards, Permission Slips
summary: Most Popular News. Consumers seem to welcome facial recognition when the technology benefits them, such as by speeding up lines or stopping crimes, according to cybersecurity and biometric specialists. But, they say, companies shouldn't rush to roll out these systems without safeguards, including procedures for obtaining customer consent and ethics boards to advise on privacy protection.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: How To Be a Happy and Relaxed Host
summary: Najmieh Batmanglij shares her secrets. The cookbook author also dishes on the best brands of basmati, her kitchen playlist and the life-changing power of ice-cold vodka. A DETAILED MAP unfolds when you open "Cooking In Iran" (Mage Publishers), the latest cookbook by Najmieh Batmanglij. It traces the contours and regions of the mountainous country as well as those that border it, bringing into vivid focus a part of the world unfamiliar to many Americans.

title: At 30-Year Low, U.S. Birth Rate Shows Striking Differences Between States
summary: The number of babies born in 2017 was the lowest in 30 years, but some states were much more fertile than others. The birthrate in America has been declining, but some places are more fertile than others, according to a new look at federal data that reveals significant variation in fertility rates around the country. Only South Dakota's and Utah's fertility rates reached the level needed to sustain the current population.

title: Surprise Winner Declared in Congo Presidential Election
summary: The electoral commission said opposition leader Félix Tshisekedi took the most votes, contradicting a tally by the country's Catholic Church. The Democratic Republic of Congo's electoral commission declared opposition leader Félix Tshisekedi as the winner of the Dec. 30 presidential election, a stunning announcement that contradicts an unofficial tally by the largest observer mission and throws the Central African nation into uncharted territory.

title: Stock Disconnect: Mainland Chinese Investors Buy Fewer Shares in Hong Kong
summary: Chinese investors cool on Hong Kong shares but investors in the city warm up to equities in Shanghai and Shenzhen. Chinese equity inflows to Hong Kong's stock market fell for the first time last year since a trading link with mainland China launched in 2014, with the city attracting less than a quarter of what it did in 2017.

title: Manhattan's Famed Chrysler Building Is Put Up for Sale
summary: Faced with high costs and stiff competition from new towers, the art deco landmark's owners have hired CBRE to market it. New York City's iconic Chrysler Building is up for sale.

title: Bezos Divorce Clouds His Stake in Amazon
summary: CEO Jeff Bezos is the company's largest shareholder with a 16.3% stake. Amazon.com Inc. Chief Executive Jeff Bezos and his wife, MacKenzie, are divorcing after 25 years of marriage, a period during which Mr. Bezos amassed a personal fortune while building the world's most valuable company.

title: Stocks Finish Day With Gains After Fed Minutes
summary: Major indexes end the day higher, lifted by signs that the central bank will stay flexible with its interest-rate rises. U.S. stocks are on their swiftest rebound in nearly a decade, fueled by reinvigorated confidence in the domestic economy and signals the Federal Reserve will take a cautious path on future interest-rate increases.

title: Ahead of 2020, Harris Touts Role in Multistate Mortgage Settlement
summary: In new book, potential Democratic presidential candidate describes clash with JPMorgan CEO. WASHINGTON-California Sen. Kamala Harris, a potential 2020 Democratic presidential candidate, engaged in an intense back-and-forth with JPMorgan Chase & Co. CEO James Dimon in 2012 as she pressed for a more comprehensive settlement for states in the aftermath of the mortgage meltdown.

title: Tom Steyer Won't Run for President, Will Focus Efforts on Trump Impeachment
summary: Steyer plans to spend at least $40 million on impeachment efforts in 2019. WASHINGTON-Tom Steyer, a billionaire environmentalist from California, said Wednesday he wouldn't seek the Democratic presidential nomination in 2020, focusing instead on his multimillion-dollar effort to impeach President Trump.

title: Supreme Court Reexamines Touchy Question of State Sovereignty
summary: Case on using one state's courts to sue another state opens broader discussion on when precedents should be allowed to stand. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court delved Wednesday into a question the framers left unresolved and the justices themselves couldn't quite answer three years ago: whether a resident of one state can use its courts to sue another state.

title: New York Senate Majority Leader Lays Out Progressive Plan
summary: Democrat Andrea Stewart-Cousins is first woman to serve as president of the chamber. The new leader of the New York state Senate pledged to pass laws to boost voter turnout, strengthen campaign-finance restrictions and ethics enforcement, and remove barriers for immigrants and transgender people as the Legislature convened Wednesday in Albany.

title: U.S. and China Make Progress on Trade, but Major Hurdles Remain
summary: The sides remain divided on issues such as a reduction of Chinese subsidies to domestic firms and protection of intellectual property. BEIJING-The U.S. and China wrapped up their first face-to-face trade negotiations since a temporary tariff truce was declared last month, making progress toward an agreement but leaving the thorniest issues to be resolved in higher-level talks, according to people with knowledge of the discussions.

title: Europe's Baby Steps on Iran
summary: New sanctions help. Now work with the U.S. for a better nuclear deal.. The European Union on Tuesday imposed new sanctions against Iran for the first time since the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action came into effect. This is a welcome, if belated, acknowledgment that the 2015 nuclear deal has failed to change Tehran's behavior.

title: White House Meeting Started With Sweets, but Quickly Turned Sour
summary: Trump and congressional leaders remain at odds over border-wall funding; 'Bye bye!'. WASHINGTON-President Trump opened the latest face-to-face negotiations with lawmakers like he was comforting members of one of his golf clubs. He made sure everyone had coffee and offered snacks-Butterfingers, M&M's and Baby Ruths.

title: Big Pharma's Cancer Race
summary: After tax reform, companies invest in innovation rather than tax arbitrage.. Not long ago America's political class was fretting about too many "me-too" drugs. Eli Lilly 's bid for Loxo Oncology , which follows a flurry of biotech deals, shows how the pharmaceutical landscape is fast-evolving as U.S. drug companies compete to become leaders in oncology.

title: Europe Settles Some Tax Scores
summary: Finally, glimmers of a new old way to account for tax cuts and growth.. Americans are used to debating the impact of tax policy on economic growth, so it might come as a surprise (or not) that the European Union is far behind the curve in this regard. New research helping Brussels fill that gap is a breath of fresh air.

title: Return of the Nominations Blockade
summary: Democrats lost Senate seats, but they're still blocking appointees.. The U.S. Senate is back in session, and therefore so is the Democratic nominations blockade. Minority Leader Chuck Schumer demanded Wednesday that President Trump withdraw his nomination of Bill Barr as Attorney General, even though Mr. Barr served with distinction as President George H.W. Bush's AG. The question is whether Senate Republicans are going to do anything more to overcome this deliberate political obstruction than they did in the last two years.

title: Democrats' Cynical 'No' on Immigration
summary: They could strike a deal for reform but would rather posture for political points.. Will Democrats ever say yes to immigration reform? They now have an opportunity to do so as President Trump demands funding for additional miles of physical barrier along the southern border.

title: Mrs. Robinson and the Missing Princess
summary: Why would Ireland's former president weigh in on an Arab heiress's psychiatric condition?. Sheikha Latifa bint Mohammed al-Maktoum wasn't seen in public for almost a year. In March 2018 Princess Latifa, the 33-year-old daughter of Dubai's absolute ruler, was planning to claim asylum at the U.S. Embassy in India when she was allegedly seized by Indian and Emirati special forces from a yacht in the Arabian Sea and, apparently, returned home. Then-silence.

title: How Sweden Overcame Socialism
summary: It's a model for the U.S., but the lesson isn't what Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez thinks it is.. Nearly half of millennials say they prefer socialism to capitalism, but what do they mean? "My policies most closely resemble what we see in the U.K., in Norway, in Finland, in Sweden," Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez told "60 Minutes." Yet Sweden's experiment with socialist policies was disastrous, and its economic success in recent decades is a result of market-based reforms.

title: Why the Fed Should Heed the Market
summary: Stock trends are the best predictor of growth. Recent volatility should give the central bank pause.. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, perhaps hoping to instill confidence, said in his press conference last month, "Of course we're always data dependent." But which data? There are countless indicators economists can seek out to track growth, employment and inflation. Picking the right ones is half the battle in making sound predictions.

title: Criminal Records for Obsolete Crimes
summary: When pot is made legal, old convictions should be expunged.. There's been a revolution in America's attitude about marijuana. Two-thirds of voters favor legalization. Nine out of 10 are OK with medical use. Ten states and the District of Columbia have legalized marijuana for recreational use, and more are expected to follow suit.

title: Behind Xi's Bluster Is a Vulnerable China
summary: Trump's policies have America surging, while Chinese growth could slow further still.. President Xi Jinping observed the 40th anniversary of China's shift from doctrinaire communism to quasi-capitalist totalitarianism by delivering a televised speech last month in unyielding authoritarian language. Yet his forceful posturing couldn't hide his concern. America's main economic rival is under real pressure to give up many of the mercantilist policies it has relied on for decades to prop up growth.

title: The Right's Resistance
summary: They are unalterably supportive of Donald Trump's presidency, flawed vessel or not.. The reasons offered for why Donald Trump won't win re-election in 2020 continue to pile up. His approval rating is stuck, seemingly forever, below 45%. The Wall Street Journal/NBC poll puts the percentage of voters who say they're likely to vote for him at 38%, while some 52% currently prefer a Democratic candidate.
